citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
*A 2-year-old, male, black French Bulldog with microchip 99200000378304 was noted with multiple areas of patchy or
partial hair loss and red skin – to include all four legs and feet, belly, face, and neck. The dog was noted scratching during
inspection. The skin was reddened in many areas and there were multiple red bumps or lesions. The toenails were also
overgrown. ** A 2-year-old, female English Bulldog with microchip 956000013899933 was noted squinting with both eyes
and with eyelids appearing wet. Upon closer examination both eyes had thick white-yellow discharge on the surface of the
eye and surrounding fur and the tissue around both eyes was red and swollen. The licensee has not consulted a
veterinarian about either dog even though the problems had been noted prior to inspection. Failure to adequately assess
and treat skin and eye problems can lead to increased and unnecessary pain and prolonged suffering. Squinting is a
significant indicator of pain. Skin issues can be a result of problems such as but not limited to trauma, parasites, allergies,
and other medical problems. The licensee must ensure that all animals showing signs of veterinary medical problems are
evaluated in a timely manner by a veterinarian as part of the facility’s programs of adequate veterinary care and that the
facility uses appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases, and injuries. These dogs must be
evaluated in person by a veterinarian. The outcome of this consultation including the diagnosis, treatment plan and how
the condition will be resolved must be documented and provided to the inspector upon request.
To be corrected in 24 hours, by noon June 15th, 2023.

There was one dog out of 22 that had no official form of identification on it at time of inspection. Identification is essential
to ensure that each dog can be properly identified and to facilitate accurate record keeping and tracking. This dog must be
identified by means of an official tag affixed to a collar, legible tattoo marking approved by the Administrator, or microchip.
The licensee must ensure that all dogs have proper identification on them at all times.
Correct by June 21st, 2023.

The licensee is not properly identifying puppies that are less than 16 weeks old. Nine puppies from 2 different litters are
being housed in the same primary enclosure and had no form of individual identification. Appropriate identification of dogs
and puppies is necessary to meet recordkeeping requirements for inventory, disposition, transport, and healthcare
documentation. The licensee must properly identify puppies with an acceptable form of identification, which include a
cage card (if litters are not comingled), a microchip, a collar and tag, or a plastic-type collar with the required information
legibly written. Correct by: June 21st, 2023.

*One of the 22 dogs on hand was not listed on APHIS Form 7005. ** Multiple 7006 records were missing required
information – to include: Date of Disposition, Complete Buyer information, Dealer’s License Number, Identification
Number and Age or Date of Birth. Complete records of animals facilitate the inspection process and enable the movement
and care of animals covered by the Animal Welfare Act to be evaluated. Each dealer and exhibitor shall use Record of
Acquisition and Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS Form 7005) and Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats (APHIS Form
7006) forms to make, keep, and maintain required information concerning each dog, unless a variance is granted by
APHIS.
To be corrected by: June 21st, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee verbally on June 14 (given 24 hours to see veterinarian)
and in writing on June 15.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
*A 2-year-old, male, black French Bulldog with microchip 99200000378304 was noted with multiple areas of patchy or 
partial hair loss and red skin – to include all four legs and feet, belly, face, and neck. The dog was noted scratching during 
inspection. The skin was reddened in many areas and there were multiple red bumps or lesions. The toenails were also

eye and surrounding fur and the tissue around both eyes was red and swollen. The licensee has not consulted a 
veterinarian about either dog even though the problems had been noted prior to inspection. Failure to adequately assess 
and treat skin and eye problems can lead to increased and unnecessary pain and prolonged suffering. Squinting is a 
significant indicator of pain. Skin issues can be a result of problems such as but not limited to trauma, parasites, allergies, 
and other medical problems. The licensee must ensure that all animals showing signs of veterinary medical problems are 
evaluated in a timely manner by a veterinarian as part of the facility’s programs of adequate veterinary care and that the

the condition will be resolved must be documented and provided to the inspector upon request.  
To be corrected in 24 hours, by noon June 15th, 2023. 
2.50(a)(1) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
There was one dog out of 22 that had no official form of identification on it at time of inspection. Identification is essential 
to ensure that each dog can be properly identified and to facilitate accurate record keeping and tracking. This dog must be 
identified by means of an official tag affixed to a collar, legible tattoo marking approved by the Administrator, or microchip. 
The licensee must ensure that all dogs have proper identification on them at all times. 
 Correct by June 21st, 2023. 
2.50(a)(2) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
The licensee is not properly identifying puppies that are less than 16 weeks old. Nine puppies from 2 different litters are 
being housed in the same primary enclosure and had no form of individual identification. Appropriate identification of dogs

and puppies is necessary to meet recordkeeping requirements for inventory, disposition, transport, and healthcare 
documentation. The licensee must properly identify puppies with an acceptable form of identification, which include a 
cage card (if litters are not comingled), a microchip, a collar and tag, or a plastic-type collar with the required information 
legibly written. Correct by: June 21st, 2023. 
2.75(a)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
*One of the 22 dogs on hand was not listed on APHIS Form 7005. ** Multiple 7006 records were missing required 
information – to include: Date of Disposition, Complete Buyer information, Dealer’s License Number, Identification 
Number and Age or Date of Birth. Complete records of animals facilitate the inspection process and enable the movement 
and care of animals covered by the Animal Welfare Act to be evaluated. Each dealer and exhibitor shall use Record of 
Acquisition and Dogs and Cats on Hand (APHIS Form 7005) and Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats (APHIS Form 
7006) forms to make, keep, and maintain required information concerning each dog, unless a variance is granted by 
APHIS. 
To be corrected by: June 21st, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee verbally on June 14 (given 24 hours to see veterinarian) 
and in writing on June 15.
